title: Antifragile, sustainable and agile healthcare waste chain network design by considering blockchain, resiliency, robustness and risk
definition: While resiliency and robustness emphasize maintaining the status quo and only show flexibility in reaction to disturbances without actively seeking improvement, antifragility emphasizes improvement and learning from disruptions.

title: Synergistic Closedâ€Loop Supply Chain Network Design by Considering Robustness, Risk: An Automotive Case Study
definition: Antifragility is achieved by designing the system to benefit from disruptions

title: The implications of Industry 4.0 for managing supply chain disruption and enhancing supply chain resilience: a systematic literature review
definition: “Supply chain antifragility has emerged as a way of not only managing disruptions but also leveraging them as opportunities for growth.”

title: The implications of Industry 4.0 for managing supply chain disruption and enhancing supply chain resilience: a systematic literature review
definition: “Antifragile supply chains not only withstand volatility and shocks but also thrive and improve from such disturbances.”

title: The implications of Industry 4.0 for managing supply chain disruption and enhancing supply chain resilience: a systematic literature review
definition: “Unlike robustness and resilience, which aim to withstand or return to a pre-shock state, antifragility suggests a capacity for evolutionary improvement in the face of adversity.”

title: Crisis Response Modes in Collaborative Business Ecosystems: A Mathematical Framework from Plasticity to Antifragility
definition: “Antifragility has been conceptually defined in terms of convex responses and asymmetric gains under stress.”

title: Antifragility and organizations: an organizational design perspective
definition: Antifragility refers to a system’s ability to benefit from disruptions and volatility—managing disturbances not only by enduring stress but by learning, adapting, and profiting from it.

title: Antifragility model development for businesses in the cosmetics industry
definition: “The concept of antifragility, introduced by Taleb (2012), offers a strategic alternative by proposing that businesses can improve and expand when exposed to volatility.”

title: Building an antifragile supply chain: A capability blueprint for resilience and postâ€disruption growth
definition: “Antifragility … is focused specifically on growth. It posits that a system can strengthen and grow through exposure to volatility and shocks, analogous to muscle growth through exercise.”

title: Building an antifragile supply chain: A capability blueprint for resilience and postâ€disruption growth
definition: “An antifragile supply chain is one that derives gains—both financial and non-financial—from disruption.”

title: Transport collaboration network among competitors to improve supply chain antifragility
definition: Antifragility emphasizes the capacity of business ecosystems to become more resilient in the face of VUCA events, fostering adaptability, flexibility, and learning from disruptions within the supply chain.

title: Evaluation of Critical Success Factors for Antifragile Supply Chains Using Delphi and Fuzzy QFD Methods
definition: “Antifragility characterizes systems that benefit from volatility and chaos, demonstrating enhanced performance when exposed to significant and seemingly unlikely variations in parameters.”

title: Evaluation of Critical Success Factors for Antifragile Supply Chains Using Delphi and Fuzzy QFD Methods
definition: “While antifragility includes the aspect of robustness, which entails recovering from shocks, it goes further by striving to achieve an even higher level of performance subsequent to such shocks.”

title: Evaluation of Critical Success Factors for Antifragile Supply Chains Using Delphi and Fuzzy QFD Methods
definition: “This emerging concept aims to endure extreme events … fostering learning, adaptation, and the exploitation of opportunities to enhance performance and foster growth.”

title: Introducing Antifragility Analysis Algorithm for Assessing Digitalization Strategies of the Agricultural Economy in the Small Farming Section
definition: “Antifragility refers to when a system benefits from the variability of its environment, and fragility refers to when it suffers.”

title: Introducing Antifragility Analysis Algorithm for Assessing Digitalization Strategies of the Agricultural Economy in the Small Farming Section
definition: “The ability to deal with uncertainty completely and internally consistently is an essential characteristic of antifragility.”

title: Betting on the future: how to build antifragility in innovative start-up companies
definition: “Antifragility implies the tendency of an organization to improve its own competitive position in the face of a crisis, while resilience does not.”

title: Betting on the future: how to build antifragility in innovative start-up companies
definition: “An antifragile firm benefits from disorder.”

title: Navigating Uncertainties in the Built Environment: Reevaluating Antifragile Planning in the Anthropocene through a Posthumanist Lens
definition: “Taleb’s theory of antifragility describes a system’s ability to withstand stress and change caused by capital, large-scale, and massive events, that are largely unpredictable; nonetheless, at the core of antifragility is the idea of thriving and improving in response to various kinds of shocks.”

title: THE EFFECT OF DIGITAL GOVERNANCE TO STIMULATE THE ANTIFRAGILE CAPABILITIES OF PUBLIC SECTOR ORGANIZATIONS
definition: “Taleb… suggested establishing a robust yet transformative and emergent environment, which equips the system with the knowledge and capacity to deal with and capitalize on uncertainty.”

title: THE EFFECT OF DIGITAL GOVERNANCE TO STIMULATE THE ANTIFRAGILE CAPABILITIES OF PUBLIC SECTOR ORGANIZATIONS
definition: “Antifragile organizations are better prepared to respond to crises and emerge more robust… transforming [risks] into opportunities.”

title: From Industry 4.0 Digital Manufacturing to Industry 5.0 Digital Society: a Roadmap Toward Human-Centric, Sustainable, and Resilient Production
definition: No definition

title: Significant Leap In The Industrial Revolution From Industry 4.0 To Industry 5.0: Needs, Problems, And Driving Forces
definition: “Antifragility, a critical characteristic of systems that thrive under stress, shocks, errors, and failures, will play a pivotal role in ensuring adaptability and robustness in the face of global challenges, such as climate change and biodiversity issues.”

title: Data-driven digital transformation and the implications for antifragility in the humanitarian supply chain
definition: “Antifragility goes beyond resilience by proposing that systems have the potential to not just survive but also flourish and gain advantages from these very disruptions.”

title: Antifragile, sustainable, and agile supply chain network design by considering resiliency, robustness, risk, and environmental requirements
definition: “Antifragility is a new concept that designers of SCND increase the capability of facilities to cope with types of disruptions like stressors, fluctuations, volatility, and shocks.” 2. “The resilient policy is flexible against shocks and back to normal mode, but the antifragility concept utilizes disruptions and moves to improvement.”

title: BUILDING SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCE AND ANTIFRAGILITY: STRATEGIES AND TECHNOLOGIES FOR MITIGATING DISRUPTIONS
definition: “Supply chains that are resilient and antifragile—capable of surviving and thriving amid disruptions.”

title: Correction to: Antifragile, sustainable, and agile supply chain network design by considering resiliency, robustness, risk, and environmental requirements
definition: “The antifragility concept utilizes disruptions and moves to improvement.”

title: Thrive during a crisis: the role of digital technologies in fostering antifragility in small and medium-sized enterprises
definition: “Antifragility, instead, represents the capability of a system to absorb shocks and get better.”

title: An operationalization of antifragility in inventory management
definition: Antifragility refers to a system’s capacity to increase performance when exposed to increasing uncertainty, representing a continuous or bounded function in which gains rise with volatility.

title: Stocks and cryptocurrencies: Antifragile or robust? A novel antifragility measure of the stock and cryptocurrency markets
definition: “A system is antifragile when it benefits from noise or disorder. Thus, noise acts as a constructive element that allows the system to perform a function successfully. Therefore, one expects to encounter antifragility in a complex dynamical system that is nonlinear, has many degrees of freedom and is out of equilibrium.”

title: Beyond resilience: towards antifragility?
definition: “Antifragility is positioned as a progression from robustness and resilience, with a positive end-point. Where robustness ends in failure, and resilience restores the status quo (plus/minus some possible lasting impacts on performance), antifragility theoretically would result in permanent positive improvement and enhanced performance.”

title: Health Service Implementation and Antifragile Characteristics in Rural Communities: A Dirt Research Approach
definition: “When programs or units are antifragile, they stand to gain from inevitable volatility rather than be harmed by it.”

title: Analyzing antifragility among smallholder farmers in Bihar, India: An assessment of farmersâ€™ vulnerability and the strengths of positive deviants
definition: “A system is antifragile when it gains from disturbances (Taleb, 2012). The average performance of an antifragile system increases as perturbations trigger selection and removal of underperforming system features, while the strongest features survive.”

title: Investigating the interaction of factors for implementing additive manufacturing to build an antifragile supply chain: TISM-MICMAC approach
definition: “While a resilient supply chain aims at absorbing shocks, an antifragile supply chain sees these shocks as an opportunity to get stronger and better. An antifragile supply chain does not only respond to disruption but also thrives in it (Taleb, 2012).”

title: Provide a Lean and Agile Strategy for an Antifragile Sustainable Supply Chain in the Construction Industry(residential complex)
definition: No definition

title: Resilience, robustness, and antifragility: Towards an appreciation of distinct organizational responses to adversity
definition: “Organizations can experience three distinct outcomes after facing adversity: (1) performance degradation followed by recovery (i.e., resilience), (2) insensitivity to uncertainty (i.e., robustness), and (3) upside gain (i.e., antifragility).”

title: Enhancing Antifragile Performance of Manufacturing Systems through Predictive Maintenance
definition: “Antifragility is the feature of a system that increases in resilience or robustness as a result of the harmful effects of stressful actions: malfunctions, shocks, errors, noise, mistakes, disturbances, attacks, faults, or failures. In other words, some systems (natural or artificial) can improve their performance and become better when subjected to various forms of stress.”

title: Exaptive innovation in constraint-based environments: lessons from COVID-19 crisis
definition: No definition

title: Gaining from disorder: Making the case for antifragility in purchasing and supply chain management
definition: “Unlike robust or resilient supply chains, the antifragile supply chain ‘loves’ disorder and thrives in the world of randomness. In other words, robust and resilient supply chains are placed on a continuum from the fragile to antifragile supply chain.”

title: Empowering Organisations to Gain From Uncertainty: a Conceptualisation of Antifragility Through Leveraging Organisational Routines in Uncertain Environments
definition: “The concept of gaining from uncertainty referred to as antifragility.”

title: Designing antifragile social-technical information systems in an era of big data
definition: Antifragility refers to the design of information systems that leverage uncertainty for gains, shifting design philosophy from preserving function to expanding functionality and performance across a range of uncertain conditions.

title: Antifragile philosophy in R&D projects: Applying Q methodology and the possibility of open innovation
definition: “The concept of antifragile was created by Nicholas Nasim Taleb in 2012. It is a neologism that Taleb uses to define the opposite to ‘fragile’… the opposite is what not only does not deteriorate, break down and/or collapse but also improves.”

title: A managerial operationalization of antifragility and its consequences in supply chains
definition: “Antifragility refers to systems that gain from volatility and disorder and show an improvement in performance when subjected to large and seemingly implausible changes in parameters. Antifragility encompasses robustness as it means the ability to recover after a shock, however, with the addition to achieve an even higher performance level afterwards.”

title: Approaches for resilience and antifragility in collaborative business ecosystems
definition: “Antifragility – when systems absorb shocks and get better afterward.” (Taleb, 2012; Hespanhol, 2017)

title: Approaches for resilience and antifragility in collaborative business ecosystems
definition: “Taleb called it antifragile and introduced the concept of antifragility as a property beyond robustness and resilience.” (Russo & Ciancarini, 2017)

title: Approaches for resilience and antifragility in collaborative business ecosystems
definition: “According to Taleb (2012), the idea behind antifragility is to survive (even thrive) in the age of complexity and volatility when dealing with unknown randomness and disruptions.” (Taleb, 2012; Russo & Ciancarini, 2017; Hespanhol, 2017)

title: Approaches for resilience and antifragility in collaborative business ecosystems
definition: “Antifragility and fragility are degrees on a spectrum, and we can almost always detect antifragility (and fragility) using a simple test of asymmetry: anything that has more upside than downside (convex) from random events (or certain shocks) is antifragile. Anything that acts reversely is fragile.” (Russo & Ciancarini, 2017)

title: Approaches for resilience and antifragility in collaborative business ecosystems
definition: “While a robust or resilient system resists failure and remains the same or recovers from failure, an antifragile system benefits from shocks, getting better.” (Lichtman et al., 2016; Hespanhol, 2017)

title: On the meaning and operationalization of antifragility: Comment on the paper by GroÎ²ler
definition: “Antifragility refers to systems which gain from volatility and disorder and show an improvement in performance when subjected to large and seemingly implausible changes in parameters.”

title: Antifragility Predicts the Robustness and Evolvability of Biological Networks through Multi-Class Classification with a Convolutional Neural Network
definition: “Antifragility can be defined as the ability of a system to improve its functionality in the presence of external perturbations.”

title: Black-Swan Type Catastrophes and Antifragility/Supra-resilience of Urban Socio-Technical Infrastructures
definition: “Antifragility … demonstrates itself as the ability of a system to become stronger (up to an unknown point) after experiencing a stressor.”

title: Black-Swan Type Catastrophes and Antifragility/Supra-resilience of Urban Socio-Technical Infrastructures
definition: “Antifragility is principally more than resilience or robustness.”

title: A Philosophy of Security Architecture Design
definition: “There may exist vulnerabilities and there may be exposure, but steps will be taken to mitigate weaknesses. title: Supraresilience of bio-socio-technical infrastructures
definition: “Antifragility … did not exist as a notion before Nicholas Taleb introduced it in 2012 as an antonym to fragility and demonstrates itself as the ability of a system to become stronger (up to an unknown point) after experiencing a stressor.”

title: Designing decentralized knowledge management systems to effectuate individual and collective generative capacities
definition: “The term ‘Antifragility’ defines the property or capacity of systems (beyond robustness and resilience) to potentially benefit or even thrive when exposed to these change or disorder effects.”

title: PANDEMIC PLANNING AND RESPONSE AND THE CASE FOR ANTI-FRAGILITY
definition: No definition

title: A collaborative approach to resilient and antifragile business ecosystems
definition: No definition

Taleb (2013): ‘Antifragility is beyond resilience or robustness. The resilient resists shocks and stays the same; the antifragile gets better.’”

title: Emergence of Antifragility by Optimum Postdisruption Restoration Planning of Infrastructure Networks
definition: “A system is antifragile if its performance improves as the result of exposure to stressors, shocks, or disruptions.”

title: Storytelling as a strategy in managing complex systems: using antifragility for handling an uncertain future in reliability
definition: “Antifragility refers to when [a system] benefits from this variability.” (Taleb, 2012; Taleb & Douady, 2013)

definition: “‘Antifragility’ essentially describes systems that actually benefit from disorder, rather than suffer.”

title: Corporate real estate black swan strategies: Beyond probability and resilience
definition: “Antifragility… regenerates itself continuously by using, rather than suffering from, random events, unpredictable shocks, and volatility.”

title: Corporate real estate black swan strategies: Beyond probability and resilience
definition: “The resilient resists Black Swans and remains the same but the antifragile knowledge gets better and better.”

title: Corporate real estate black swan strategies: Beyond probability and resilience
definition: “Antifragility is defined as a convex response to a source of harm and so can lead to a positive response to an increase in volatility, as opposed to fragility which suffers from the variability of its environment beyond a certain pre-set threshold.”

title: Building antifragility in service organisations: going beyond resilience
definition: The implications of antifragility go beyond resilience or robustness. A resilient system resists stress and remains the same; while an antifragile system improves.” (Jaaron & Backhouse, 2014; citing Taleb, 2012)

title: Building antifragility in service organisations: going beyond resilience
definition: “To maintain organisational growth in a turbulent environment, organisations must build highly effective learning systems to innovate and develop from threats and stressors. This has been termed by Taleb (2012s) as ‘antifragility.’” the capacity to learn from stressors in order to flourish.”
